recipes.name: Soya Kheema Paratha
directions: Step 1: Boil 1 cup of water with 1 tablespoon of milk and a pinch of salt. Once boiling vigorously, remove from heat and add the soya chunks. Set aside for 10 minutes.

Step 2: Drain the soya chunks and rinse with cold water at least twice to remove any raw smell. Squeeze out excess water completely and pulse grind in short bursts, two or three times, until coarsely ground.
Step 3: Heat oil in a pan. Add fennel seed powder, followed by chopped onion and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until golden brown.
Step 4: Add red chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala powder to the pan. Mix well. Add a little water and bring to a boil.
Step 5: Add the ground soya kheema to the pan and mix well. Cook over low heat for 3 minutes, or until the spices are well combined with the kheema.
Step 6: Mix wheat flour with water to form a soft, pliable dough. Divide the dough into equal parts and roll each part into a smooth ball.
Step 7: Lightly flour a surface and roll out each dough ball slightly thicker than a regular chapati. Place a portion of the soya kheema filling in the center of each rolled-out dough circle.
Step 8: Gather the dough from all sides to enclose the filling completely. Seal tightly.
Step 9: Flip the filled dough over and roll it out into a paratha, either thick or thin, dusting with flour as needed.
Step 10: Heat a flat griddle or tawa. Carefully place the parathas on the hot tawa, drizzle with oil, and cook until golden brown on both sides.

Use soft, diffused natural light to highlight the textures.  A dark, rustic wooden background and a linen napkin should complement the paratha. Garnish with fresh coriander sprigs.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the torn section, with a warm, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Aloo Paratha (Potato-Stuffed Flatbread)
ingredients: 1 teaspoon oil, plus more for cooking
1 teaspoon cumin seeds or 1/2 teaspoon carom seeds (ajwain)
All-purpose flour or whole wheat flour, for dusting
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Dough: In a large mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water, mixing until a soft, pliable dough forms. Add 1 teaspoon of oil and knead for 2-3 minutes until smooth and non-sticky. Cover the dough and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.

Step 2: Prepare the Potato Filling: Boil the potatoes until tender. Drain and mash them thoroughly. In a pan, heat a teaspoon of oil. Add cumin seeds or carom seeds and let them splutter. Add the mashed potatoes, turmeric powder, and salt. Sauté for 2-3 minutes, then stir in the chopped coriander leaves. Remove from heat and set aside to cool.

Step 3: Assemble the Parathas: Divide the dough and the potato filling into equal-sized portions. Roll each dough portion into a circle, slightly thicker than a regular chapati. Place a portion of the potato filling in the center of the dough circle. Gather the edges of the dough and seal it completely, enclosing the filling.

Step 4: Roll and Cook the Parathas: On a lightly floured surface, gently roll out the stuffed dough into a thin, circular paratha. Heat a flat griddle or tawa over medium heat. Place the paratha on the hot tawa and cook for 2-3 minutes per side, or until golden brown spots appear. Drizzle with oil or ghee as needed while cooking.
Step 5: Serve: Serve the hot aloo parathas with yogurt, chutney, or pickle.

Use a dark, rustic wooden surface as the backdrop with a linen napkin casually draped nearby. Garnish with fresh coriander sprigs and a small bowl of yogurt. Employ soft, diffused natural light from the side to highlight the textures. Shallow depth of field, focusing on the torn edge of the top paratha, creating a blurred background. Aim for a warm, inviting mood that emphasizes the comforting nature of the dish.  Include a subtle sheen from a brush of oil on the parathas.

recipes.name: Masala Chapati
ingredients: 2 teaspoons Oil or Ghee, plus extra for toasting
directions: Step 1: In a large bowl, combine the wheat flour, chili powder, turmeric powder, curd, garam masala powder, kasoori methi, chat masala powder, cumin seeds, sugar, and salt.
Step 2: Gradually add water while mixing until a dough begins to form. Add the oil or ghee and knead for 5 minutes until the dough is soft and pliable.
Step 3: Cover the dough and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.
Step 4: Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls and flatten them slightly.
Step 5: Dust a clean surface with flour and roll each ball into a thin chapati.
Step 6: Heat a flat griddle or dosa pan over medium heat. Place a chapati on the hot surface and drizzle with a little oil or ghee.
Step 7: Cook for 1-2 minutes per side, or until golden brown spots appear and the chapati is cooked through.
Step 8: Serve hot with your favorite curry or chutney.

recipes.name: Cabbage Paratha (Savory Cabbage Flatbread)
ingredients: 3/4 cup finely chopped or grated Cabbage
directions: Step 1: Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan. Add the chopped cabbage and sauté until it wilts and the raw smell disappears.
Step 2: In a large bowl, combine the wheat flour, salt, garam masala (if using), chili powder, turmeric powder, and chopped coriander leaves.
Step 3: Add the sautéed cabbage to the dry ingredients and mix well.
Step 4: Gradually add water, mixing and kneading until a soft dough forms. Cover the dough and let it rest for 15-30 minutes.
Step 5: Divide the dough into equal, lemon-sized portions. Roll each portion into a thin circle or square paratha.

Step 6: Heat a flat griddle or tawa. Place a rolled paratha on the hot tawa and cook for 1-2 minutes per side, or until golden brown spots appear. Add remaining 1 tbsp oil to the parathas while they are cooking.
Step 7: Serve the hot parathas with pickles or yogurt.

recipes.name: Kathi Rolls with Mixed Vegetables
ingredients: 3/4 cup mixed vegetables (carrot, capsicum, and beans), chopped lengthwise
1/2 teaspoon garam masala or chaat masala
directions: Step 1: In a large bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, all-purpose flour, and salt. Gradually add milk, kneading until a soft dough forms. Cover and let rest while preparing the filling.
Step 2: Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan. Add the sliced onions and sauté until golden brown. Add the ginger-green chili paste and sauté for a minute.

Step 3: Add the chopped mixed vegetables to the pan and sauté for 3 minutes, or until slightly tender but still crisp. Add the turmeric powder, garam masala or chaat masala, and lemon juice. Mix well.
Step 4: Cover the pan and cook for 2 more minutes. Remove from heat.
Step 5: Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls. On a lightly floured surface, roll each ball into a thin circle, similar to a chapati.
Step 6: Heat a dosa pan or griddle. Cook each rolled-out paratha on both sides until lightly browned.
Step 7: To serve, lightly toast the parathas with a little oil. Spread green chutney on each paratha, add a spoonful of the vegetable filling, and roll tightly from the bottom up.
Step 8: Wrap the bottom of each roll with butter paper or foil to prevent leakage and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Green Pea Paratha
ingredients: 1 ½ cups Green Peas (fresh or frozen)
directions: Step 1: In a mixing bowl, combine the wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water and knead until a smooth and pliable dough forms. Set aside to rest.

Step 2: Pressure cook the green peas for one whistle (if using frozen peas, use a minimal amount of water, just enough to immerse them). Allow the peas to cool. Meanwhile, coarsely grind the green chilies. Add the cooked peas to the ground chilies and grind coarsely.

Step 3: Heat oil in a pan. Add shahi jeera and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until lightly browned. Add the pea mixture, garam masala, and salt. Sauté for 2 minutes, or until the spices are well combined. Stir in the coriander leaves and remove from heat.

Step 4: Divide the dough and pea stuffing into equal-sized balls. Make the stuffing balls slightly smaller than the dough balls. Roll out each dough ball into a thick circle. Place a stuffing ball in the center and seal it by pulling the edges of the dough towards the center.

Step 5: Seal the paratha completely and roll it into a thin or thick circle, dusting with flour as needed to prevent sticking. Heat a flat griddle or tawa and cook the paratha, drizzling with oil, until golden brown spots appear on both sides. Serve hot, brushed with ghee.

recipes.name: Chilli Parotta
directions: Step 1: Chop the parottas into small squares using kitchen scissors. Toast them on a tawa for 3-5 minutes until lightly crisp. Set aside.
Step 2: Heat 2 teaspoons of oil in a pan. Add the roughly chopped onion and minced garlic, sauté until lightly browned. Add the chopped tomatoes and sauté until softened and the raw smell disappears.

Step 3: Add coriander powder, garam masala powder, and salt to the pan. Stir well and cook until the mixture shrinks slightly. Add cashews and poppy seeds, sauté for 2 minutes. Remove from heat and allow to cool.
Step 4: Grind the cooled mixture into a fine paste. Set aside.
Step 5: Heat the remaining oil in the same pan. Add the chopped onion and sauté until lightly browned. Add the chopped green capsicum and sauté for a minute.
Step 6: Add the prepared tomato-onion paste and tomato sauce to the pan. Season with salt and chili powder. Sauté until the mixture is semi-dry.
Step 7: Add the toasted parotta pieces to the pan and toss well to coat them evenly with the sauce. Cook over medium-high heat for 2 minutes, or until the mixture becomes dry.
Step 8: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve hot.

recipes.name: Rajma Paratha (Kidney Bean Flatbread)
ingredients: ½ tablespoon Coriander Leaves, finely chopped
directions: Step 1: Soak the kidney beans (rajma) in enough water for at least 6-8 hours or overnight. Rinse well.
Step 2: Pressure cook the soaked rajma with enough water and the optional clove for 5-6 whistles, or until soft. Drain the water and reserve it.
Step 3: Lightly mash the cooked rajma and set aside.
Step 4: In a wide bowl, combine the wheat flour, salt, and 2 tablespoons of oil. Gradually add water and knead into a soft dough, similar to chapati dough. Cover and let rest for at least 30 minutes.
Step 5: Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them crackle.
Step 6: Add the chopped onion and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until the onion is lightly browned.
Step 7: Add the mashed rajma, turmeric powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt to the pan. Mix well.
Step 8: Gradually add the reserved rajma water to achieve a pasty consistency. Bring the mixture to a boil and cook until it thickens and forms a cohesive mass.
Step 9: Stir in the chopped coriander leaves and remove from heat.
Step 10: Divide the dough into equal portions. Roll each portion slightly thicker than a regular chapati.
Step 11: Place a spoonful of the rajma filling in the center of each rolled-out dough circle.
Step 12: Gather the edges of the dough and seal it completely, enclosing the filling.
Step 13: Gently flatten the filled dough ball with your palms.
Step 14: Roll out the paratha carefully, ensuring the filling doesn't leak out. Dust with flour as needed to prevent sticking.
Step 15: Heat a flat griddle or tawa. Cook the paratha on both sides, drizzling with a little oil, until golden brown spots appear.

recipes.name: Masala Palak Paratha (Spinach Flatbread)
directions: Step 1: Heat the oil in a pan. Add the cumin seeds and carom seeds and allow them to splutter.
Step 2: Add the chopped green chili and sauté for a few seconds. Then add the chopped spinach and sauté until it wilts and reduces in volume.
Step 3: Once the spinach has wilted, remove from heat and stir in the chopped coriander leaves. Let the mixture cool completely.
Step 4: Grind the cooled spinach mixture into a smooth paste using a blender or food processor.
Step 5: In a large mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, spinach paste, turmeric powder, garam masala powder, and salt.
Step 6: Gradually add water, a little at a time, and knead the mixture into a soft, pliable dough. Cover the dough and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
Step 7: Divide the dough into equal, lemon-sized balls. On a lightly floured surface, flatten each ball slightly.
Step 8: Roll out each flattened ball into a thin, circular paratha. You can make them slightly thicker if preferred.
Step 9: Heat a flat griddle or tawa over medium heat. Transfer a rolled paratha to the hot tawa.
Step 10: Drizzle a little oil around the edges of the paratha and cook for 1-2 minutes, or until brown spots appear on the underside.
Step 11: Flip the paratha and cook the other side for another 1-2 minutes, drizzling with a little more oil if needed, until golden brown spots appear.
Step 12: Repeat with the remaining dough balls. Serve the hot parathas with raita, dal, or your favorite side dish.

recipes.name: Savory Oats Roti
ingredients: 1 teaspoon Oil + as needed for cooking
directions: Step 1: Grind the rolled oats into a fine powder using a blender or food processor.
Step 2: In a large mixing bowl, combine the oat powder and wheat flour.
Step 3: Add the oil, red chili powder, finely chopped onion, coriander leaves, and salt to the dry ingredients. Mix well.
Step 4: Gradually add water while mixing to form a smooth, pliable dough, similar to chapati dough. Knead the dough for 5-7 minutes until it becomes soft and elastic.
Step 5: Divide the dough into equal, lemon-sized balls. Cover the dough balls with a damp cloth and let them rest for 15-30 minutes.

Step 6: On a lightly floured surface, roll out each dough ball into a thin circle using a rolling pin. Dust with flour as needed to prevent sticking. Be gentle while rolling as the roti can tear easily.
Step 7: Heat a flat griddle or tawa over medium heat.
Step 8: Carefully place the rolled roti on the hot tawa.
Step 9: Drizzle a little oil around the edges of the roti.
Step 10: Cook for about 1-2 minutes per side, or until brown spots appear and the roti is cooked through. Flip and cook the other side similarly.
Step 11: Serve the savory oats roti hot with your favorite chutney, curry, or raita.

recipes.name: Gobi Paratha (Cauliflower Flatbread)
directions: Step 1: Blanch the cauliflower florets in hot water to clean them. Drain and dry completely, then grate finely using a grater or food processor. Set aside.
Step 2: Heat 2 teaspoons of oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them crackle. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté until golden brown.
Step 3: Add the grated cauliflower, salt, red chili powder, turmeric powder (if using), and garam masala to the pan. Mix well.
Step 4: Sauté until the raw smell of cauliflower disappears. Cover and cook for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally. Sprinkle a little water if needed to help cook faster.
Step 5: Continue to sauté over medium heat for another 5 minutes, until the cauliflower is soft and well-cooked.
Step 6: Stir in chopped cilantro and remove from heat. The filling is now ready.
Step 7: Divide the dough into equal portions and roll each portion into a smooth ball.
Step 8: Lightly flour a surface and roll out one dough ball slightly thicker than a regular chapati.
Step 9: Place a generous spoonful of the cauliflower filling in the center of the rolled-out dough.
Step 10: Gather the edges of the dough and seal it completely, encasing the filling.
Step 11: Flatten the filled dough gently with your palms and then carefully roll it out into a paratha, ensuring the filling doesn't leak out. Dust with flour if needed to prevent sticking.
Step 12: Heat a flat griddle or tawa. Cook the paratha on both sides, drizzling with a little oil, until golden brown and cooked through.
Step 13: Serve the gobi parathas hot with raita or your preferred side dish.

recipes.name: Methi Chapathi (Fenugreek Flatbread)
ingredients: 3/4 cup roughly chopped fresh methi (fenugreek) leaves
directions: Step 1: Sauté the chopped methi leaves in a pan with a little oil until they shrink and reduce in volume. This helps remove any bitterness.
Step 2: In a large bowl, combine the wheat flour, salt, coriander powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, curd, besan flour, oil, and turmeric powder.
Step 3: Add the sautéed methi leaves to the dry ingredients.
Step 4: Gradually add water while mixing to form a soft, pliable dough. The dough should be similar in consistency to a roti dough.
Step 5: Cover the dough and let it rest for 15-30 minutes.
Step 6: Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls and roll them into smooth spheres.
Step 7: On a lightly floured surface, roll each ball into a thin circle (roti/chapati).
Step 8: Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat.
Step 9: Carefully place a rolled roti on the hot tawa.
Step 10: Drizzle a little oil around the edges and cook until brown spots appear on both sides.
Step 11: Flip and cook the other side similarly.
Step 12: Serve the methi chapathi hot with onion raita, pickle, or your favorite side dish.

recipes.name: Mooli Paratha (Radish Flatbread)
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine the wheat flour and salt. Mix well to distribute the salt evenly.

Step 2: Gradually add water (or reserved radish water) to the flour mixture, mixing until a soft, pliable dough forms. Add 1/2 teaspoon of oil and knead briefly. The dough should be smooth and non-sticky, neither too tight nor too loose. Cover and let the dough rest while preparing the filling.
Step 3: Peel and grate the radish. Place the grated radish in a colander with the turmeric powder and gently squeeze out excess water. Set aside.
Step 4: Heat oil in a pan. Add ajwain seeds and let them splutter.
Step 5: Add the chopped onion and sauté until lightly browned.
Step 6: Add the grated radish, red chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala powder, cumin powder, and salt to the pan. Mix well and sauté for 5-7 minutes, or until the mixture is dry.
Step 7: Stir in the chopped coriander leaves. Remove from heat and set aside.
Step 8: Divide the dough and the radish filling into equal-sized portions. The filling portions should be slightly smaller than the dough portions.

Step 9: Roll each dough portion into a thick circle. Place a portion of the radish filling in the center of each circle. Bring the edges of the dough together to enclose the filling completely, pinching and sealing the seams.
Step 10: Gently flatten the filled dough balls and roll them into thin or thick parathas, dusting with flour as needed to prevent sticking.
Step 11: Heat a flat griddle or tawa. Cook the parathas on the hot griddle, drizzling with oil or ghee, until golden brown spots appear on both sides.
Step 12: Serve hot, brushing with additional ghee if desired.

recipes.name: Chapati Noodles
ingredients: 1/4 cup tightly packed Cabbage, thinly sliced lengthwise
directions: Step 1: Prepare the vegetables: Thinly slice the onion, cabbage, carrot, and capsicum lengthwise. Mince the garlic.
Step 2: Cut the chapatis: Stack 2-3 chapatis and cut them into four squares. Then, cut each square in half and slice into thin strips.

Step 3: Sauté the vegetables: Heat the cooking oil in a pan or wok. Add the onion and garlic and sauté until lightly browned. Add the carrot and cabbage and sauté until the raw smell disappears, cooking over medium-high heat to prevent burning. Add the capsicum and sauté for a minute.
Step 4: Add sauces and seasonings: Add the soya sauce, tomato sauce, and salt to taste. Mix well.
Step 5: Combine with chapati strips: Add the chapati strips to the pan and mix well with the vegetables and sauce. Simmer for 2 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Step 6: Serve: Remove from heat and serve immediately.

scenes.voice_over: Now, add the soy sauce, tomato sauce, and salt. Mix well to combine.

scenes.voice_over: Add the chapati strips to the pan and gently mix them with the vegetables and sauce. Simmer for about 2 minutes, stirring occasionally, until heated through.

scenes.voice_over: Remove from heat and serve your chapati noodles immediately. They're delicious on their own or as a side dish.

recipes.name: Instant Akki Roti (Masala Rice Roti)
directions: Step 1: In a wide bowl, add the rice flour. Crush the cumin seeds with your hands and add them to the flour.
Step 2: Add the chopped onion, ginger, chili powder (if using), turmeric powder, grated carrot, grated coconut, chopped coriander leaves, asafoetida, and chopped green chili to the bowl.
Step 3: Add salt to taste. Gradually add water, little by little, while mixing the ingredients until a soft dough forms. Be careful not to add too much water at once.
Step 4: Lightly grease a piece of plastic wrap or a flat surface with oil. Pinch a small lemon-sized ball of dough and pat it thinly on the greased surface, similar to making a chapati.
Step 5: Heat a dosa tawa or griddle. Place the roti on the hot tawa and drizzle with a little oil. Cook until golden brown on one side, then flip and cook the other side until done.
Step 6: Repeat the process for the remaining dough balls. Serve the rotis hot with chutney or tomato ketchup.

recipes.name: Sabudana Khichdi
ingredients: 1/2 tablespoon finely chopped fresh coriander leaves
directions: Step 1: Rinse the sago pearls thoroughly under running water until the water runs clear. Soak the sago in enough water to just immerse it overnight, or for at least 4-6 hours, until softened. Do not over-soak, as this will make the khichdi mushy.
Step 2: Dry roast the peanuts in a pan over medium heat until golden brown. Roughly crush the peanuts; do not powder them.
Step 3: Pressure cook the potatoes for 4 whistles, or until soft. Peel and cube the cooked potatoes.
Step 4: Heat the oil or ghee in a pan over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds, ginger, curry leaves, and green chili. Sauté until the spices splutter.
Step 5: Add the cubed potatoes and a pinch of salt to the pan. Stir well and cook for a minute.

Step 6: Add the soaked sago pearls to the pan. Cook, stirring frequently, until the sago turns translucent. Be careful not to mash the sago and ensure it doesn't stick to the bottom of the pan. If it starts to stick, gently fluff it up.
Step 7: Add the crushed peanuts and sugar (if using) to the pan. Mix well.
Step 8: Stir in the lemon juice. Garnish with grated coconut and coriander leaves. Mix well and remove from heat.

nutrition.sugar: 5-7 grams per serving (can vary depending on added sugar)

recipes.name: Vegetable-Stuffed Paratha
ingredients: 1 cup finely chopped mixed vegetables (carrots, green beans, and cabbage)
2 tablespoons finely chopped green bell pepper
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Filling: Finely chop the mixed vegetables (carrots, green beans, and cabbage) using a food processor or sharp knife. In a pressure cooker, combine the chopped vegetables with salt, turmeric powder, and enough water to immerse them. Cook over medium heat for 2 whistles. Mash the cooked vegetables and reserve the cooking liquid.

Step 2: Make the Dough: In a large mixing bowl, combine the mashed vegetables, whole wheat flour, chili powder, cumin powder, garam masala (if using), chopped green bell pepper, coriander leaves, and salt. Gradually add the reserved vegetable cooking liquid and, if needed, additional water to form a soft, pliable dough. Knead the dough for a few minutes until smooth. Cover and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.

Step 3: Roll and Cook the Parathas: Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls. Dust a rolling surface with flour and roll each ball into a thin or thick paratha (as desired). Heat oil in a flat griddle or tawa over medium heat. Cook the parathas one at a time, flipping them once or twice, until golden brown and cooked through on both sides.

recipes.name: Rava Khichdi
directions: Step 1: Heat 1/2 tablespoon of ghee in a pan. Fry the cashews until golden brown and set aside. In the same pan, dry roast the rava until fragrant, without changing its color. Set aside.
Step 2: In a pressure cooker, combine the chopped carrots and peas. Pressure cook on medium heat for 2 whistles, until partially cooked. Set aside.

Step 3: Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and chana dal. Fry until the lentils turn golden brown. Add ginger paste and sliced onions. Fry until the onions are lightly browned. Add chopped tomatoes and fry until softened.
Step 4: Add the partially cooked carrots and peas to the pan. Sauté for 2 minutes. Add turmeric powder and salt. Sauté until the vegetables are well combined.
Step 5: In a separate pot, bring 3 cups of water to a boil. Carefully pour the boiling water into the pan with the vegetables and spices.
Step 6: Gradually add the roasted rava while stirring continuously. Lower the heat and continue stirring to prevent lumps from forming.
Step 7: Cook covered for 3-5 minutes, or until the rava absorbs the water and the khichdi reaches a slightly mushy consistency.
Step 8: Stir in the chopped coriander leaves, fried cashews, and lemon juice. Mix well. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Triangle Paratha
ingredients: 1 tablespoon ghee, plus extra for layering
directions: Step 1: In a large bowl, combine the flour, ghee, oil, salt, and cumin seeds. Mix well.
Step 2: Gradually add water and mix to form a smooth, pliable dough. Knead for 5 minutes until soft. Cover and let it rest for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
Step 3: Knead the dough once more and divide it into 7 lemon-sized balls.
Step 4: On a lightly floured surface, roll out each ball into a thin circle.
Step 5: Spread a few drops of ghee evenly over the circle. Fold it in half into a semicircle, spread more ghee, and fold again into a triangle.
Step 6: Roll the triangle into a thin paratha, dusting with flour as needed to prevent sticking.
Step 7: Heat a flat griddle or tawa over medium heat.
Step 8: Cook the paratha for 2-3 minutes per side, or until golden brown spots appear and it is cooked through, flipping when bubbles start to appear. Add more ghee or oil as needed while cooking.
Step 9: Serve hot.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of golden-brown triangle parathas, layered with visible ghee, on a rustic wooden board. Use a slightly overhead angle with selective focus on the flaky layers of the closest paratha.  Soft, diffused natural light should highlight the textures and warm tones.  Garnish with a small bowl of cumin seeds and a sprig of cilantro.  Shallow depth of field with a muted, earthy background creates a warm and inviting mood. Incorporate negative space for a balanced composition.

video_script.title: Crispy Triangle Paratha Recipe
video_script.description: Learn to make flaky and delicious Triangle Parathas at home with this easy-to-follow recipe.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a golden brown, crispy triangle paratha, served with a bowl of yogurt and chutney. Steam gently rising.
scenes.voice_over: Hello, and welcome! Today, we're making delicious, crispy Triangle Parathas – a popular South Asian flatbread. These parathas are flaky, buttery, and perfect for any meal.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients are arranged on a wooden table: flour, ghee, oil, salt, cumin seeds, and water. Measurement tools, like cups and spoons are also placed alongside.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 tablespoon of ghee, 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil, salt to taste, 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds, and about 1 cup of water.

scenes.image_prompt: A large bowl with flour, ghee, oil, salt, and cumin seeds. A hand is mixing the ingredients together.
scenes.voice_over: In a large bowl, combine the flour, ghee, oil, salt, and cumin seeds. Mix them well until combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Water being gradually added to the flour mixture as someone kneads it into a smooth dough.
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add water and mix until a smooth, pliable dough forms. Knead for about 5 minutes until soft and slightly elastic. Cover and let it rest for 30 minutes to an hour.

scenes.image_prompt: The dough is divided into 7 equal, lemon-sized balls.
scenes.voice_over: Once rested, knead the dough briefly and divide it into 7 equal, lemon-sized balls.

scenes.image_prompt: One of the dough balls is being rolled out into a thin circle on a lightly floured surface using a rolling pin.
scenes.voice_over: On a lightly floured surface, roll each ball into a thin circle, about 6-7 inches in diameter.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the process of folding the circle with ghee: half-circle, then triangle with ghee spread on each layer.
scenes.voice_over: Spread a thin layer of ghee over the circle. Fold it in half into a semicircle, then spread more ghee and fold again into a triangle.

scenes.image_prompt: Rolling the triangle into a paratha on a floured surface with a rolling pin.
scenes.voice_over: Now, carefully roll the triangle into a thin paratha, dusting with flour as needed.

scenes.image_prompt: Cooking paratha on a hot tawa, flipping it and adding ghee for even cooking.
scenes.voice_over: Heat a flat griddle or tawa over medium heat. Cook the paratha for 2-3 minutes per side, or until golden brown spots appear. Flip when bubbles start to form and add more ghee or oil as needed.

scenes.image_prompt: Several cooked triangle parathas stacked on a plate, served with yogurt, chutney, and a cup of chai/tea.
scenes.voice_over: Serve your hot, crispy Triangle Parathas with yogurt, chutney, or any of your favorite sides. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a flakier paratha, use a combination of ghee and oil.
Adjust the amount of water depending on the flour used.
Do not overcook the paratha, or it will become dry and hard.
Serve with your favorite curry, chutney, or yogurt.

recipes.name: Aloo Gobi Paratha (Potato and Cauliflower Flatbread)
ingredients: 2 cups Wheat Flour, plus extra for dusting
2 medium Potatoes, boiled and mashed (approximately 1 cup)
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Dough: In a large bowl, combine the wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water, mixing until a soft, pliable dough forms. Add 1/2 teaspoon of oil and knead briefly. Cover and let the dough rest while you prepare the filling.

Step 2: Prepare the Filling: Soak the cauliflower florets in salted warm water. Cook the cauliflower until soft. Boil the potatoes until tender, then peel and mash them. Drain any excess water from the cauliflower and potatoes. Mash the cooked cauliflower with the potatoes until no lumps remain.

Step 3: Cook the Filling: Heat oil or ghee in a pan. Add ajwain seeds and ginger-green chili paste. Add the mashed potatoes and cauliflower along with turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for 3 minutes over low heat. Stir in chat masala powder and remove from heat. Add chopped coriander leaves (if desired).

Step 4: Assemble the Parathas: Divide the dough into equal portions. Roll out each portion into a thin circle. Place 2 spoonfuls of the aloo gobi filling on one half of the circle. Fold the other half over the filling to form a semi-circle. Seal the edges by pressing with your fingers.

Step 5: Cook the Parathas: Heat a flat griddle or tawa. Cook the parathas on both sides until golden brown spots appear, drizzling with oil or ghee as needed. Repeat with the remaining dough and filling. Serve hot, brushed with ghee or yogurt.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three Aloo Gobi Parathas, slightly overlapping, on a rustic wooden board.  Garnish with a dollop of yogurt and a sprinkle of chopped cilantro. Use a dark, textured background with soft, diffused natural light from the side, highlighting the golden-brown crust and the texture of the parathas.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the front paratha's flaky layers and the yogurt.  Aim for a warm, inviting, and slightly rustic mood.  Include a small bowl of pickle in the background, slightly out of focus.

Adjust the spices according to your preference.

recipes.name: Egg Kothu Parotta
directions: Step 1: Chop the parottas into small pieces and set aside.
Step 2: Heat oil in a large pan or skillet over medium heat. Add fennel seeds and let them splutter. Add curry leaves and green chilies, and sauté for a few seconds until fragrant.
Step 3: Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté until lightly browned.
Step 4: Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften and turn slightly mushy.
Step 5: Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and black pepper powder. Mix well and sauté for a minute.
Step 6: Add salt to taste.
Step 7: Crack the egg into the pan and scramble it well, mixing it with the spices and vegetables. Cook until the egg is fully cooked and well combined.
Step 8: Add the chopped parottas to the pan and mix thoroughly, ensuring the parotta pieces are coated with the egg and masala mixture.
Step 9: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Remove from heat and serve immediately.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stunning, close-up image of Egg Kothu Parotta, highlighting its textural complexity.  The shredded parotta, infused with turmeric's golden hue, should be the focal point, with a shallow depth of field blurring the background.  Use a dark, rustic backdrop and wooden serving board. Garnish with fresh coriander sprigs and a wedge of lime. Lighting should be soft and directional, emphasizing the steam rising from the dish and the glistening oil on the parotta. Employ a slightly overhead angle, showcasing the chopped onion, tomato, and egg incorporated within.  Evoke a warm, inviting mood.

video_script.title: Egg Kothu Parotta: A South Indian Delight
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious Egg Kothu Parotta, a flavorful and easy South Indian street food recipe.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of Egg Kothu Parotta, garnished with coriander leaves. Steam rising from the dish.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome to our kitchen! Today we're making Egg Kothu Parotta, a popular South Indian street food. It's a quick, easy, and incredibly flavorful dish that's perfect for any meal.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of all the ingredients neatly arranged on a wooden table: chopped parottas, egg, chopped onions, chopped tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, black pepper powder, ginger-garlic paste, vegetable oil, fennel seeds, curry leaves, green chilies, salt, and coriander leaves.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: two parottas, one egg, one onion and one tomato, both finely chopped. Spices include turmeric powder, red chili powder, black pepper powder, ginger-garlic paste, and salt. We'll also be using vegetable oil, fennel seeds, curry leaves, green chilies, and fresh coriander for garnish.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of chopping the parottas into small pieces on a cutting board.
scenes.voice_over: First, chop your parottas into bite-sized pieces and keep them aside.

scenes.image_prompt: A pan on medium heat with oil, fennel seeds spluttering, and curry leaves and green chilies being added.
scenes.voice_over: Heat a tablespoon of oil in a pan over medium heat. Add half a teaspoon of fennel seeds and let them splutter.  Then add 10 to 12 curry leaves and two slit green chilies. Sauté for a few seconds until fragrant.

scenes.image_prompt: The pan with ginger-garlic paste being sautéed until lightly browned.
scenes.voice_over: Add one teaspoon of ginger-garlic paste and sauté for about a minute until it's lightly browned.

scenes.image_prompt: Onions and tomatoes being cooked in the pan until softened.
scenes.voice_over: Add the chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown, about 5 minutes. Then add the chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften, about 3 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Dry spices being added to the pan and mixed well.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add a quarter teaspoon of turmeric powder, one teaspoon of red chili powder, and half a teaspoon of black pepper powder. Mix well and sauté for about a minute until fragrant.

scenes.image_prompt: An egg being cracked into the pan and scrambled with the spices and vegetables.
scenes.voice_over: Crack the egg directly into the pan and scramble it thoroughly, mixing it well with the spices and vegetables. Cook until the egg is fully cooked.

scenes.image_prompt: Chopped parottas being added to the pan and mixed with the egg and masala mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Add the chopped parottas to the pan. Mix everything thoroughly, making sure the parotta pieces are nicely coated with the egg and masala mixture.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of garnishing the Egg Kothu Parotta with coriander leaves.
scenes.voice_over: Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves. Remove from heat, and your Egg Kothu Parotta is ready! Serve hot and enjoy!

scenes.image_prompt: A plate of Egg Kothu Parotta served with a side of raita and a wedge of lime. Close-up shot.
scenes.voice_over: Egg Kothu Parotta is delicious on its own, but you can also enjoy it with raita or a squeeze of lime. Each serving has approximately 350 calories, 12 grams of protein, 50 grams of carbs, and 15 grams of fat.  Give this recipe a try, and let us know what you think in the comments below!

cooking_tips: You can adjust the amount of spices according to your preference.
For a richer flavor, use ghee instead of oil.
Add other vegetables like chopped carrots, peas, or beans for a more nutritious meal.

recipes.name: Roti (Phulka)
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine the flour and salt. Mix well to distribute the salt evenly.

Step 2: Gradually add water to the flour mixture, mixing until a soft, pliable dough forms. Add the oil (if using) and knead the dough until smooth and non-sticky. The dough should not be too firm or too soft.
Step 3: Cover the dough and let it rest for 15-30 minutes.
Step 4: After resting, knead the dough again briefly. Divide the dough into lemon-sized balls.
Step 5: On a lightly floured surface, roll each dough ball into a thin, circular roti (approximately 6-7 inches in diameter).
Step 6: Heat a flat griddle or tawa over medium heat.
Step 7: Place a roti on the hot tawa and cook until small bubbles appear on the surface.
Step 8: Flip the roti and cook for another minute until golden spots appear.
Step 9: Using tongs, carefully transfer the roti directly to a high flame on the stovetop. Cook for a few seconds on each side, puffing up the roti.
Step 10: Remove the puffed roti from the flame and place it in a roti basket or insulated container to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining dough balls.
Step 11: Serve hot with your favorite curry or side dish. Optionally, brush with ghee or butter before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stack of three freshly made, puffed rotis (phulkas) on a rustic wooden board.  Use soft, diffused natural light from the side to highlight the airy texture and golden-brown color. A shallow depth of field focuses on the foreground roti, with the others slightly blurred. Incorporate a small bowl of ghee or a simple linen napkin as props.  Shoot from a slightly elevated angle to showcase the puffed nature of the rotis.  The overall mood should be warm, inviting, and appetizing.

video_script.title: Soft & Fluffy Roti (Phulka) Recipe
video_script.description: Learn how to make perfect, soft, and fluffy roti (phulka) with this easy-to-follow recipe.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a stack of golden brown, puffed rotis in a basket, steam gently rising. A bowl of curry is placed next to it.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making delicious, soft, and fluffy roti, also known as phulka. These are a staple in many Indian households and pair perfectly with any curry.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of the ingredients neatly arranged on a wooden surface. Whole wheat flour in a bowl, salt in a small dish, a measuring cup with water, and a small bowl with oil.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: one cup of atta (whole wheat flour), half a teaspoon of salt, about half a cup of water, and optionally, half a teaspoon of oil.

scenes.image_prompt: Mixing bowl with flour and salt, a hand gradually adding water while mixing with a spoon.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine the flour and salt. Gradually add water and mix until a soft, pliable dough forms. If using, add the oil and knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl covered with a damp cloth, containing the dough.
scenes.voice_over: Cover the dough and let it rest for at least 15-30 minutes. This allows the gluten to relax, resulting in softer rotis.

scenes.image_prompt: Hands dividing the dough into small, lemon-sized balls on a lightly floured surface.
scenes.voice_over: After resting, briefly knead the dough again. Divide it into equal, lemon-sized balls.

scenes.image_prompt: Rolling out a dough ball into a thin circle on a lightly floured surface using a rolling pin.
scenes.voice_over: On a lightly floured surface, roll each dough ball into a thin, circular roti, about 6-7 inches in diameter.

scenes.image_prompt: A roti cooking on a hot tawa, small bubbles starting to appear on the surface.
scenes.voice_over: Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat. Place the roti on the hot tawa and cook for about 30-45 seconds until bubbles appear.

scenes.image_prompt: Flipping the roti on the tawa and cooking the other side.
scenes.voice_over: Flip the roti and cook for another minute until golden spots appear.

scenes.image_prompt: Puffing up the roti on a high flame using tongs, showing the roti expanding with air.
scenes.voice_over: Using tongs, carefully place the roti directly on a high flame for a few seconds per side. This will puff it up beautifully.

scenes.image_prompt: A stack of puffed rotis in a roti basket, served with a bowl of curry and a side of raita.
scenes.voice_over: Place the puffed roti in a container to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining dough. Serve hot with your favorite curry, raita, or any side dish. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For softer rotis, use warm water for kneading the dough.
Do not overcook the rotis, as they can become dry and hard.
Store leftover rotis in an airtight container to maintain freshness.
